content.body: A Coq Mechanization of JavaScript Regular Expression Semantics: https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3674666
In 6.1, they acknowledge the distinction between main-body and annex B regexes, but don't explicitly say which they're mechanizing (as far as I could see). I'm pretty sure it's just main-body.
Do the two modes have different _features_, or just different parsing rules?
content.formatted_body: Do the two modes have different features, or just different parsing rules?

content.body:
> These grammars do not agree on all inputs:
for instance, the standard grammar rejects ], whereas the legacy grammar allows it and treats it as
a valid regex matching the character ‘]’. Given this, we left parsing out of our mechanization.
content.formatted_body:
These grammars do not agree on all inputs:
for instance, the standard grammar rejects ], whereas the legacy grammar allows it and treats it as
a valid regex matching the character ‘]’. Given this, we left parsing out of our mechanization.

content.body: It's mostly syntax, but it isn't *just* syntax, some of the pseudocode is different too, so it makes a difference (to the resulting mechanization) which you pick.
content.formatted_body: It's mostly syntax, but it isn't just syntax, some of the pseudocode is different too, so it makes a difference (to the resulting mechanization) which you pick.

content.body:
> <@nicolo-ribaudo:matrix.org> Do the two modes have different _features_, or just different parsing rules?

just different parsing rules AFAICT, but the interpretation of various `\c…` in various possible locations gets _really_ intricate
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @nicolo-ribaudo:matrix.org
Do the two modes have different features, or just different parsing rules?
just different parsing rules AFAICT, but the interpretation of various \c… in various possible locations gets really intricate

content.body: For research purposes, it makes sense for them to stick to the main-body, but I think it's at least worth saying so.
